B0000026NC|3.0|The Delicate Sound of Thunder is the worst live album that Pink Floyd, or any incarnation thereof, ever released. Not, as some would have you believe, the best live document of a band whose 27-year recording career was dwarfed by their fantastic stage shows. Jernau (two reviews down) has several things wrong in his 5-star review. Perhaps he should take a look at a proper discography, or maybe just actually read the liner notes to those albums he professes such misplaced affection for. <br /> <br />Most of the reviews here compare the Delicate Sound of Thunder with  PULSE, two virtually-indistinguishable post-Roger Waters live albums. Jernau rightly points out that Pink Floyd have another live album, 1969's Ummagumma. But Syd Barrett, the \\"Crazy Diamond\\" alluded to in practically every Floyd album since his departure, was long gone by that time. The live material on that quaint old 60's double-album has a very strange nervous energy-- the band are working like gangbusters to put on that they never needed Syd in the first place. Kind of like what is attempted on Delicate Sound, only it takes an army of session players to replace Syd AND Roger. <br /> <br />What's this about material from The Final Cut on the Delicate Sound disc? I don't see any, maybe because none was played. Richard wasn't even around for that record, and Nick was hardly there at all. Why should they trot out cuts from a record that they had so little to do with? Like, say, A Momentary Lapse of Reason? Oh, I know, because David Gilmour tells them to. Momentary Lapse is so grossly over-represented here: this is one of many cases where Pink Floyd were releasing a record simply to make a point about what they were capable of doing without one of their former members. <br /> <br />Now, for PULSE on the other hand (which is, despite what Jernau claims, EXACTLY the same band, except for the saxophonist and backup singers who do much better jobs respectively), we have a finer balance between the old and newsongs, with more polished and considered performances. A complete run-through of Dark Side of the Moon (instead of the disjointed, muddled performances here on Delicate Sound) is a feather in PULSE's cap. Plus the sound is shimmering with brightness and clarity, traits nowhere to be found on Delicate Sound of Thunder. However, since by this time Pink Floyd were all about visuals and not, God forbid, breaking new musical ground, the video versions (soon to be DVD for PULSE) are superior in both cases. <br /> <br />Olly Buxton (immediately below me) has it right in his review. DST is still a guilty pleasure, for a great many reasons... not least of which is the inclusion of \\"Dogs of War,\\" widely considered the most humiliating Pink Floyd song in their whole canon. Well, the Floyd at their worst are still better than most bands at their best. But maybe Mr. Buxton should listen to Roger Waters's \\"In the Flesh - LIVE\\" album or better yet the DVD, where his session men actually manage to capture the intimacy and warmth of the pre-Wall Pink Floyd far better than David Gilmour & Pink Floyd 1987 Ltd. could ever hope to do.

B00028HBKM|5.0|Movies can be depressing, exciting, expressive, influential, and the list goes on.  The key as a director is to capture as many of these traits as possible while making a simple modern film.  Some have accomplished feat, however not many.  Mel Gibson, with hard work and descriptive work accomplished when he directed The Passion Of Christ.  The film can be described with countless adjectives, including depressing, motivating, and accurate -to name a few-.  Mel takes you through the last days of what are known to be Jesus Christ's life.  He uses direct interpretations from the Bible, while adding his own opinions on what he believes happened thousands of years ago.  I recommend every person in the world to watch this movie.  Even though at times it can be gruesome and very gory, the theme and idea of the film are the key importance.  Even though half the world may not be Christian this film will definitely broaden the rest of the world's minds'.  Many directors have attempted to recreate the stories of the Bible, and most of them have failed with little or no success.  The Passion Of Christ took modern technology to the limits and excelled by being accepted by the current audience.  This film has taken historical interpretation to a new level.  My only request is that kids under the age of 18 should not be able to see this film.  For one, they will be more likely to understand the meaning behind the film if they are of age.  Second, modern children have been exposed to a great deal of violence; they should witness this film when they are able to distinguish between what is fiction, and what is plausible.
B00005JNEU|3.0|First of all, the book on which this film was based was the best football book that I have ever read.  But, the viewer should realize that the movie is \\"based\\" on the book's story and takes liberties so as to have a climactic finish. <br /> <br />I fully support another reviewer who was troubled by the shaky camera style of filming.  Unfortunately, this seems to be new method of filming football movies since Any Given Sunday.  It's meant to have the viewer \\"feel\\" the emotions of the frantic life of the football player, but it only leads to motion sickness for me, and it makes me doubt the strength of the script that shaking the camera is needed to draw the audience into the scene.   <br /> <br />The acting is generally good, but while the coach's character was central to the film, no attempt was ever made to better understand him.  How, for example, did he really feel about the racist comments made in his presence, and was he as ambivalent about his players outside of their playing abilities as he was portrayed in the film. B00028HBKM|5.0|Movies can be depressing, exciting, expressive, influential, and the list goes on.  The key as a director is to capture as many of these traits as possible while making a simple modern film.  Some have accomplished feat, however not many.  Mel Gibson, with hard work and descriptive work accomplished when he directed The Passion Of Christ.  The film can be described with countless adjectives, including depressing, motivating, and accurate -to name a few-.  Mel takes you through the last days of what are known to be Jesus Christ's life.  He uses direct interpretations from the Bible, while adding his own opinions on what he believes happened thousands of years ago.  I recommend every person in the world to watch this movie.  Even though at times it can be gruesome and very gory, the theme and idea of the film are the key importance.  Even though half the world may not be Christian this film will definitely broaden the rest of the world's minds'.  Many directors have attempted to recreate the stories of the Bible, and most of them have failed with little or no success.  The Passion Of Christ took modern technology to the limits and excelled by being accepted by the current audience.  This film has taken historical interpretation to a new level.  My only request is that kids under the age of 18 should not be able to see this film.  For one, they will be more likely to understand the meaning behind the film if they are of age.  Second, modern children have been exposed to a great deal of violence; they should witness this film when they are able to distinguish between what is fiction, and what is plausible.

0060512806|5.0|I bought \\"Cryptonomicon\\" after I finished \\"The Diamond Age\\" by the same author.  However, this book sat unread in my to-read pile for more than a year.  After I started it, I wondered aloud why I had waited so long to start it; when I finished it, I flipped back to the first page and began re-reading it.  Although the 900+ pages are daunting to see in your to-read pile, the book is immensely satisfying. <br /> <br />Stephenson crafts a tale of the past and present.  About half of the story takes place before and during World War II; the other half follows the descendants of the characters from the other half in their struggles in the present-day.  Each chapter follows a different character, and the book weaves the chapters from the past and present flawlessly.  We see how characters interact, and can draw parallels between the present characters and their ancestors.  We see how events from the past shape today, in ways both readily apparent and more difficult to ascertain. <br /> <br />Now that I have finished this book, I'm off to dive into his latest series, which I understand has some characters and themes in common with this book.  It certainly has the length in common, but I'm looking forward to another well-crafted story.

B000000OA6|5.0|I remember when this album was released, a friend of mine told me he saw a TV special about Queen.  He said that Freddie, in particular, looked very unhealthy in the videos for \\"I'm Going Slightly Mad\\" and \\"These Are the Days of Our Lives.\\"  Well, I think we all know what happened to Freddie Mercury just months after this release.  Although he was a fairly private person, the performance and the lyrics are Freddie's most personal.  \\"Innuendo\\" features Steve Howe of Yes on the acoustic middle 8th.  Freddie sings \\"Don't take offence at my innuendo (probably more in reference to his playful side than anything else).  Some people have compared this to the middle 8th in \\"Bohemian Rhapsody.\\"  \\"I'm Going Slightly Mad\\" is a more humourous song, with hilarious lines \\"I think I'm a banana tree\\" and \\"I'm riding only 3 wheels these days, my dear, how about you?\\"  John Deacon closes with a fast bassline.  \\"Headlong\\" is more like the oldschool Queen as is \\"I Can't Live without You,\\" both featuring some great guitar work from Brian May.  \\"Don't Try So Hard\\" is a more personal song, warning people to do their best but not kill themselves in the process. \\"Ride the Wild Wind\\" is reminiscent of \\"Don't Lose Your Head,\\" with Roger Taylor's fast and furious drums and opening narration \\"Push the envelope, don't sit on the fence!\\"  \\"All God's People\\" sounds a little like \\"Somebody to Love,\\" with its waltzy tempo and Gospel flavour.  \\"Rule with your heart and lead with your conscience,\\" Freddie preaches in the song.  This song also features the operatic harmonies that graced earlier albums like A Night at the Opera.  \\"These Are the Days of Our Lives\\" is a sensitive ballad about growing old with the one you love.  \\"No use wondering what you did when you can sit back and enjoy it through your kids.\\"  \\"Delilah\\" is a humourous song about Freddie's cat and Brian makes cat sounds with his Red Special guitar.  \\"Hitman\\" is almost a heavy metal rewrite of \\"Another One Bites the Dust.\\"  This song isprobably meant to be tongue in cheek, as it seems uncharacteristic with the rest of the album.  Brian plays a lovely romantic solo at the beginning of \\"Bjou\\" (which means \\"sacred jewel\\").  Finally, we come to the closing track, the ultimate farewell song \\"The Show Must Go On.\\"  Freddie probably knew his days were numbered but stayed strong, as you can hear with lyrics \\"Empty places, what are we living for?... I'll face it with a grin, I'm never giving in, on with the show!\\"  Though Queen parted ways after Freddie's untimely death (except for the Concert for Life, the song \\"No One But You\\" and work on the Made In Heaven project), Queen's legacy will go on.
B00005AAFS|5.0|When Rammstein released their third album \\"Mutter\\" (Mother) everyone thought that it would be the last release of the group- that is until they listened to it. When the critics and reviewers put it on they found what was really the bands strongest CD yet. There's a lot less of the techno (except for really cool mixing) and alot more rock in this album. All of the band memebers themselves they were really happy with it- especially Till because he was able to really sing to the songs (and his singing voice is phenomonal). <br /> <br />The opening song \\"Mein Herz Brent\\" (My Heart Burns) is the best opening, starting with strings (REAL strings, not sythesized crap) and Till reciting lines from an old childrens TV show dalled \\"The Sandman\\". To let you know just how pretty this song is, the music video for it was filmed as the story of Snow White (in a sinister sense, of course). It's beautiful lyrically as well, the song about a person born from a lab with no parents. The song has a beutiful musicbox part playing in the background of it while Till sings of a child who was no longer wished to live. It's sad and pretty and has a creepy child voice singing with him in the chorus. I love Till's speaking in the beginning and mid-end of the song. He sounds like he's ready a story to children! <br /> <br />\\"Zwitter\\" (Hermaphrodite) This is the most alternative sounding song on the albumn, but that doesn't mean it's bad. In fact it's again, one of the best. It makes you want to dance. It makes you sing along \\"Zwitter Zwitter!\\" The lyrics are so amusing about a complex relationship where he's in love with himself (the character in the song being a Hermaphrodite after all). Brilliantly crafted by the whole band! <br /> <br />\\"Rein Raus\\" (In, Out) THis is a song about having sex. It's one of the hardest on the album, and has this really pretty part in it before the last chorus. MOST HARDCORE. It's natually sung in German, so if you don't want your parents to know what their saying you should be safe... unless your parents are german -_- <br /> <br />\\"Adios\\" The farewell song of the album is surprisingly not the last. This one has the best guitar parts in it (well, solo wise) where they solo turns into the song and goes back into the main riff. It's brilliant and really catchy. Till does a good job singing in this one (as usual). <br /> <br />\\"Nebel\\" (Mist) THis is one of the saddest songs on the albumn, the only other REALY slow one other than \\"Mutter\\". THe story of a man and a dying woman's last kiss, which he can't remember. The melody is really different for them and proves that they can write any kind of music they want- and be successful in doing it. Till's melody line is haunting and pretty, and very heart breaking. He sings with a very raw earnestness and I think I'm ranting a bit here. Anyway, it's good -_- <br /> <br />Yes! So, this is one of the top five albums of all of the hundreds I own. B000002AVF|5.0|Maybe I'm a bit biased because #1 I'm a MASSIVE Mariah fan and #2 I happened to get this CD at a rather low point in my life in 1995, and it was so uplifting for me, but I'm sure you'll agree this album is Mariah at her best. Recorded at the height of her soaring career, Mariah played with different music styles, and she gave us a taste of what was to come in future releases (e.g. \\"Butterfly\\" and \\"Charmbracelet\\") with her first foray into serious R'n'B/Hip-Hop. Once again her amazing lyrics (which have an uncanny way of reflecting experiences and feelings of my own) shine and THAT voice soars throughout most of the songs (unfortunately not something that happens so much on her more recent albums.) <br /> <br />1. Fantasy - 10/10 - Sensational musically, lyrically and vocally. Upbeat, funky and a bit different to what were used to from Mariah, which makes this track all-the-more fantastic. The famous ODB remix rocks as well (lucky me was treated to the live version in Perth 1998!!) <br /> <br />2. Under The Stars - 8/10 - I used to think this song was rather boring but I absolutely love it now! Sounding like it could very well have been released in 1978 (which is probably one of the reasons I love it so much), UTS is smooth and sexy. <br /> <br />3. One Sweet Day - 9/10 - I guess it helped that both Mariah and the 'Boyz' were enjoying their own massive successes in 1995, but I'm sure that if this song was released in any other year, it still would have been the world-wide record-breaking smash it was then. What an amazing collaboration! - so powerful, moving and passionate. I especially love the A-Cappella version on the CD single (if you're lucky enough to have a copy - be sure to have a listen!) <br /> <br />4. Open Arms - 8/10 - I hadn't heard the original Journey version of this track prior to Mariah's (I have since rectified this music faux-pas) - and both are beautiful in their own right. Where Journey's version is passionate, Mariah's is sweet and heartfelt. As with this track, even on the softer, slower songs, Mariah's voice truly SOARS (something she does less and less of these days, unfortunately) <br /> <br />5. Always Be My Baby - 9/10 - Funky, groovy track with cute lyrics and Mariah's voice sounds amazing. I can't help but have to get up and sing along (although I can't sing!!) <br /> <br />6. I Am Free - 8/10 - I gained a whole new respect for this song at Mariah's '98 concert in Perth - she read out a letter from a member of the audience who'd recently lost her best friend (also a Mariah fan) to cancer and mentioned that this was their favourite song and was played at her funeral (Mariah then sang One Sweet Day for her.) I couldn't have thought of a song more fitting. This gospel-like song is truly uplifting and beautiful. <br /> <br />7. When I Saw You - 9.5/10 - simply beautiful lyrically, vocally and musically, this is one of my very favourite Mariah ballads. Her voice is simply amazing.  <br /> <br />8. Long Ago - 8/10 - I wasn't a huge fan of this track at first, but it's definately grown on me over the years. Especially when it later described a situation with an ex! I also love the groovy beat...a great mellowish song. <br /> <br />9. Melt Away - 7.5/10 - as with \\"Long Ago\\", I didn't like this track so much for the first year or two I had this album. But it really is beautiful - quite sensual. Quite obvious that BabyFace co-wrote and produced, though! His style is easy to pick out! <br /> <br />10. Forever - 8/10 - this was one of my favourite songs when I first purchased the CD, but where some of my lesser favourites have grown on me, this one doesn't do the same for me that it used to. However, I do love how she played with the 50's/60's ballad sound (and simplicity of lyrics)and her vocals are spectacular throughout! <br /> <br />11. Daydream (Interlude) - 7/10 - not ODB's remix, nor the Def Club mix (an 11-odd minute remix which completely rocks - crank it up if you have the Fantasy CD single!), but not too shabby. <br /> <br />12. Looking In - 7.5/10 - musically, this track is stirringly beautiful.  <br /> <br />As always, Mariah's lyrics are powerful and moving. Musically, this album is stunning - particularly the ballads, where Mariah collaborates with the amazing Walter Afanasieff - If there was an instrumental version of this album, i'd have it! And as mentioned over and over, Mariah's voice doesn't let up at all. Daydream is definitely one of my favourite Mariah Carey albums! No true Mariah fan should live without it!!!

Christina is finally moving up from pop star status, with the release of her latest C.D, entitled Stripped. By \\"Stripped\\" she doesn't mean naked, she's referring to the real Christina Aguilera, or as she's more formerly known, X-Tina. When Christina's music first came out she was a pop icon and didn't portray her true self. With the debut of this album everyone can have a peak inside the real life of \\"X-Tina.\\" <br /> Christina's life has changed drastically since her fist self titled album, \\"Christina Aguilera\\", came out. In her earlier days she was this sweet, young blond girl who was once a member of Disney's, Mickey Mouse Club. Her music mostly consisted of love ballads and up-beat dance songs, most of them written by someone other than herself. Not only was her music different than it is now, but also her entire look. She had cute, short, bleached blond hair and wore midriff baring tops and super tight bottoms. Today you can find her with the same type of outfits, but showing a lot more skin than before and her pants have gotten tighter and lower. Also her hairstyles are way more exotic than before. Not only is her hair color constantly changing, but so is the style. This is what makes her so unique. She has a style unlike any other.  <br /> Behind those short skirts and tight tops comes an amazing voice. Christina has a wonderful talent and can reach even the highest notes. If you were not a big fan of her last C.D, give her another chance. This C.D is very different from her first. She writes about real happenings in her life, including her abusive father on the track \\"I'm OK.\\" She also does a wonderful job on the anthem \\"Beautiful,\\" a deep song about how every ones beautiful in their own way. One of my favorite songs from this C.D would be \\"Walk Away.\\" It's a love song that is so beautiful and touching and the lyrics are amazing and very well written. Another song I would recommend listening to is \\"Can't hold us down\\" featuring Lil Kim. There's a part where she sings, \\"This is for my girls all around the world, who've come across a man who don't respect your worth, thinking all women should be seen, not heard.\\" Basically, she's singing about double standards for men and women. How men get away with certain actions and behaviors, but if a woman was to do the same thing it's unacceptable. I think many women can relate to not only this song, but also the others. To me, the C.D \\"Stripped\\" is a womans anthem. No matter what mood I am in I can always find a song to relate to and that is important to me in picking out a great C.D. <br /> One drawback of this C.D would be the tracks \\"Dirrty\\" and \\"Get Mine Get Yours.\\" As you can probably tell from the titles of these two songs, they are very mature and have a lot of sexual content. Although they are catchy, if you have younger children you probably would not want them listening to these songs. Don't get me wrong, they are nice if you just want to dace, but if you're looking for a song to actually listen and relate to then I wouldn't recommend these two songs. <br /> Overall I loved how Christina completely opened up and let us explore her life as she sees it. Her songs are really inspiring and the way she sings and presents them is great. Some people have bad opinions of her because of how she has changed, but I admire her for this. It's a hard thing to do, finding your true self, and she did it. If she's comfortable and happy this way then who are we to criticize her? I love her and her music and I can't wait for her next C.D to come out. Her music has inspired me and helped me through some rough times. Keep up the good work Christina! <br />

If you like blink-182 listen to this they're like blink, except better.

This book is a hilarious story of a single woman living in England, who is trying to get herself out of the financial mess she got herself into from shopping.  The worst part is she is a financial advisor for a local magazine. <br />Becky Bloomwood lives in a well known apartment complex in England with her best friend Suzy.  She writes for a financial magazine, giving information on how to use smart banking, and saving your money well.  She doesn't even like her job, and she is always finding ways to get out of press conferences, and writing the articles. <br />  Becky could take some advice from her job on financing though, because Becky herself has a hard time managing her money.  She is a shopaholic; spending her money whenever she can, and even sometimes when she can't.  Her credit cards are maxed out, and she has no more money left, but somehow she finds the money to buy that beautiful sweater in the department store window.  The bills are always pilling up in her mailbox, but she manages to find new ways to get rid of the bills.  She \\"accidentally\\" looses them, throws them out without looking at them, or hides them, because she doesn't want to know how much of a debt she is in.  She knows that she has a trouble spending money, and even tries to make herself a budget to manage her money better.  But Becky cannot fight the urge to shop when there is a sale, and sometimes is a foolish spender, buying things she doesn't need and will never use.   <br />Soon, she meets a man, Luke Brandon, from a highly successful financial company, and soon realizes that she likes him.  Then she finds out some important information about his company, that not only saves her financial situation, it changes her life, and saves Luke's company. <br />The author of this book, Sophie Kinsella, is the author of 3 different books.  She has written 2 other books in the series of the Shopaholic, Shopaholic Takes Manhattan, and Shopaholic Ties the Knot.  Both of these books go on the same adventures with Becky on spending her money and her job, but she also goes on newer adventures, traveling to America, and even meeting someone of her dreams.  Sophie has also written another book called Can You Keep a Secret? that stars a totally different character.  Sophie is now a writer, but like Becky, she used to be a journalist for a financial magazine also.   <br />This is a great book only if you are looking for a light summer read.  It's a book you would enjoy to read if you were just relaxing.  It doesn't require much thinking about what is going on in the book, because it is easy to follow what the plot is.  Also, this is not the kind of book you would read to go into big depth.  It's just an easy, fun book to read.  It is about fashion and shopping, rather than any other serious subject. She does some crazy things that I would never think to do, and she does it all just to get out of paying a bill, something we all have to do in our lives.  I would recommend reading this book, but just for something to sit back and relax to, and also to laugh about. <br />

B0000067L2|4.0|While Eric Clapton gained enormous fame as a monster guitarist in the '60s with his band Cream, it was not readily acknowledged that what he was doing was nothing radically new. Granted, Clapton had a solo style that was both bursting with power and possessed a strange lovliness; however guitarists had been achieving this particular combination for some time. What Clapton did was to crank the volume way, way up so that the ensuing frenzy really did sound like the heavens were exploding. <br /> But that's not to take away from the album's essential listenability, even if its originality is suspect. While Clapton was not destined to be the pathbreaker than Hendrix, and to a somewhat smaller extent John McLaughlin was, he had more than achieved, by the time he was in his 20s what most other musicians would never do even if they lived to be 90.  <br /> And we must not forget Baker and Bruce's contributions. The propulsive force of Baker's drum solos were as much a definition of Cream as Clapton's fire was. While guitarists of Clapton's caliber can be encountered now and again in the rock world, Baker had almost no rival--not until the emergence of jazz-rock, when Billy Cobham's harder and more \\"masculine\\" style, one with an emphasis on outrageous power and a more cerebral approach, would set the standard.  <br /> As for the album itself,its a good one, but like I said before,its good less for what it is than what it helps us understand. In that sense its more musicology than music.Still, its a great listen
0880389052|5.0|I think this book is a great beginning to the story of Drizzt. As for reviewers like Zach who like to think they are smart and enjoy using big words to somehow validate their oppinion, I would say that you think too much and your over-analysis is unfounded and inaccurate.

B000063DHL|5.0|Iron Maiden's golden age started with \\"Killers\\" and pretty much ended with \\"Somewhere in Time\\". All of the songs on \\"Somewhere\\" are ambitious, adding new elements to Maiden's sound. The guitar synth's found on \\"Somewhere\\" are present, but not as overpowering as on the follow-up cd \\"Seventh Son\\". Everything Maiden fans enjoy about the band are present on \\"Somewhere\\". Steve Harris' bass lines crackle, and Dickinson's urgent vocals really carry the album along. The guitar riffs are catchy, and hook you right away. The thing that always impressed me with Iron Maiden, was that, during the 80's most metal bands like Ratt, Posion, Motley Crue etc, were busy playing and singing about rock n' roll, girls and partying. Maiden often based their music on literature; \\"Murders in the Rue Morgue\\", poetry: \\"Rime of the Ancient Mariner\\", history; \\"Aces High\\", \\"The Trooper\\" and \\"Run to the Hills\\"; religion; \\"Heaven Can Wait\\", \\"Number of the Beast\\" and mythology \\"Icarus\\" and \\"Poweslave\\". The great epic metal tunes on Iron Maiden disks defied the conventions of the time, where most bands stuck to radio-friendly, 5 minutes or less rock anthems. Iron Maiden was, and is more than just a standard metal band, and if you are a music fan, you are doing yourself a great dis-service if you don't pick up the disks from the heyday. \\"Somewhere in Time\\" features 8 great track, each better than the one before it. Listen to \\"Alexander the Great\\" and ask yourself if any other band at the height of their popularity would have been able to put that song on a cd. The guitar riff on \\"Wasted Years\\" will be running through your head all day, and you will be humming the chorus of \\"Heaven Can Wait\\" for a long time. This is a great album, from a band that always brought a little more to the table than just catchy rock anthems.

B00000099Y|5.0|If you like Tool, and you are looking to buy your first Tool album, this is the one. Much of the work is allegorical and each time you listen to it you get a deeper and deeper meaning. Maynard's writing on this album is spectacular. The title song \\"Aenima\\" is a kick in the face of modern Hollywood-centered society and Maynard holds absolutely nothing back in his description of this \\"three-ring circus.\\" There are many other notable songs on this album including the accusatory \\"Eulogy\\" Maynard sings to (presumably) a hypocritical preacher (but who really knows). \\"Forty-six and 2\\" is about Jung's view on pyschology and evolution itself; a simple search on yahoo explains a lot about what 46 and 2 presumably means. \\"Hooker with a Penis\\" is a brilliant song about those who criticize Tool as a band that has sold out; He makes a point that if Tool sold out, and you bought the album, what does that make you? <br /> <br />Although the music isn't really as hard as a lot of other bands out there, fans of Peter, Paul, and Mary would be turned off by heavy guitar riffs, pounding drums, reverberating bass, and often vulgar language; however Maynard only uses \\"offensive language\\" to express his primal rage and frustration, and boy can he get frustrated. <br /> <br />Be prepared for a lot of randomness too. The song \\"(-)Ions\\" is just the sound of buzzing electricity with wind in the background. The song \\"Die Eier Von Satan\\" is one that I use to defend this type of heavy industrial-like music. The song is in German and Maynard screams a few verses intermixed with a steady chant. At first listen many neophytes of Tool would suggest that it is some gothic devil-worshiping chant, but those who speak German would be surprised to find that it is a recipe for cookies. Thus is the humor of Tool's frontman, Maynard James Keenan.
B00000099Y|5.0|I do not know how anyone could put Tool's talent down. Maybe you don't agree with the lyrics, maybe Maynard's voice isn't your cup of tea but Tool is the most talented band out there. I would love to see the concert that had Meshuggah with Tool. You can't go wrong with any of Tool's cds. I listen to at least one Tool cd everyday, usually on my drive to work. I believe these are his true feelings towards organized religion and the matyrdom of Jesus. There is no band out today that has more of my respect then Tool does. Anyone who likes metal, rock, alt-rock, industrial, even country should own this cd. It will make you look like a music expert.

0553573403|4.0|A great book and series, although definately not for all.<br /><br />Fantasy books too often are full of holes from sub-standard writing, poor character developement, and hackneyed plots--a poor story that is a medium for magic, swords, and the supernatural.<br /><br />You will find none of that here.<br /><br />The colorful descriptions of Westeros and its inhabitants are more than enough for any fantasy fan to enjoy, and the tired magic/flaming swords are replaced by a more intelligent and subtle kind of mystique.  The suberfugue, backstabbing, and politics of the plot help rise this series above other fantasy epics and allow for appreciation from a broader audience.  The writing, again, is one of the best I've read in fantasy thanks to the efforts of such an accomplished and experienced author as George R.R. Martin.<br /><br />That being said, although I would rate this book 5 stars among other epic fantasies, I still found a few major flaws that prevent it from appealing to many people unfamiliar with the genre.<br /><br />As with all epics, fantasy or no, this book/series is long. I personally enjoy long books and huge, epic plots,(W&P, Hyperion Cantos) but one of the bitter complaints I hear with epic fantasies is that they NEVER END. Other epic fantasies I've finished could keep my interest because of my fresh mindset at the time. Unfortunately this genre has been on a long downward spiral from over-ambitious authors and profit-hungry publicists. They keep the audience attracted with the huge scope of the story and the layers apon layers of sub plots, side stories, perspectives, etc. As I said before, Song of Ice and Fire is far above the others, but still suffers from the fundamental flaws of a fantasy epic.<br /><br />If you like suberfugue and politics, good, long, story-telling, have patience, and are tired of the same-old same-old in fantasy, I would recommend this book.<br /><br />Those of you who are squeamish of violence and sex and expect to see an ending or closure of some sort within +2000 pages of writing, beware.and expect to see an ending or closure of some sort within +2000 pages of writing, beware.

BUT IF U ALL DON'T WANNA RESEARCH STEVIE'S UNKNOWN ALTERNATIVE MATERIAL 2 GET A MORE EXPANSIVE VIEW OF THE MAN'S RICH ENDURING TALENT WELL THAT'S YOUR LOSS.IF U ALL JUST WANT ME 2 JUST WRITE ABOUT HIS HITS-WELL THEN U R N THE WRONG PLACE.I'D RATHER MUCH WRITE ABOUT HIS LEGENDARY ALTERNATIVE MATERIAL.HIS HITS BEING REPEATED OVER AND OVER AGAIN ON THE RADIO JUST DOESN'T CUT IT 4 ME.AND THIS IS WHERE THE PROBLEM LIES.PEOPLE JUST WANT HITS,HITS,HITS AND NOTHING MORE.WELL,I'M NOT ON THAT VIBE.(I LIKE THE HITS TOO,BUT THERE IS MORE LEGENDARY ALTERNATIVE MUSIC FROM STEVIE THAT DESERVES TO BE HEARD)AN ARTIST MUST GROW ARTISTICALLY AND DO OTHER THINGS.AND WHEN ARTISTS DO SOMETHING DIFFERENT THAT IS NOT OF THE NORM,THEN U THE MAINSTREAM LISTENING PUBLIC HAVE NO LISTENING PATIENCE FOR SOMETHING THAT IS DIFFERENT(A GOOD CASE IN POINT WAS WHEN STEVIE RECORDED \\"JOURNEY THROUGH THE SECRET LIFE OF PLANTS\\"(1979)WHICH WAS TRASHED AND ATTACKED BY CRITICS,MOTOWN AND SOME OF STEVIE'S FOLLOWING)BUT TO ME TO THIS VERY DAY IT IS A PIECE OF MUSICAL ART.WONDER BASICALLY CHALLENGED HIS FOLLOWING TO GROW WITH HIM AS AN ARTIST AND TO CHALLENGE THEIR MUSICAL TASTES.HIS FANS EITHER GROW WITH HIM AS AN ARTIST OR THEY DON'T.<br /><br />PRINCE IS VERY MUCH IN THE SAME VEIN AS STEVIE.(STEVIE'S LITTLE KNOWN OR UNKNOWN MATERIAL IS JUST AS GOOD OR EVEN FAR BETTER THAN HIS FAMOUS SONGS THAT HE IS KNOWN 4. VOTE HOWEVER U WANT 2 VOTE ON MY REVIEW OF THIS COLLECTION-BUT IF U CAN'T EXPAND YOUR MIND 2 STEVIE'S LITTLE KNOWN OR SONGS THAT R NOT FAMILIAR 2 U I SAY AGAIN THAT'S YOUR LOSS.EVERYONE KNOWS THE HITS,BUT WHEN ATRUE ARTIST SUCH AS STEVIE EXPANDS HIS MUSICAL PALLETE WITH SONGS<br />THAT R NOT 3 MINUTE POP RADIO HITS THEN U THE RADIO LISTENING PUBLIC HAVE NO PATIENCE 4 HIS TRUE MASTERY (AND THE MAJORITY OF U ALL HAVE SHORT MUSIC ATTENTION SPANS)AND A NARROW MINDED VIEW OF HIS MUSIC THAT U R ONLY FAMILIAR WITH THRU RADIO.BUT IN ALL HONESTY U ALL R BEING DEPRIVED IF U ONLY LISTEN 2 WHAT THEY PLAY ON THE RADIO.THIS MUSIC LEGEND HAS RECOREDED MUSIC FROM ALL DIFFERENT SCOPES AND ANGLES.HE IS A TRUE MASTER MUSICIAN THAT HAS DONE IT ALL BESIDES THE HITS THAT U R ONLY FAMILIAR WITH.<br /><br />STEVIE WONDER'S LEGENDARY MUSIC IS MORE THAN JUST HITS.DO YOUR RESEARCH-APPRECIATE AND ADMIRE HIS UNKNOWN ALTERNATIVE CLASSICS AS WELL AND STOP LETTING RADIO DICTATE 2 U ON WHAT U SHOULD BE LISTENING 2.IF U ALL DON'T WANNA LISTEN 2 THE ABOVE SONGS THAT STEVIE HAS WRITTEN 4 OTHER ARTISTS-THAT'S YOUR CHOICE.IF NOT,WELL THEN I DON'T CONSIDER U ALL 2 BE TRUE STEVIE WONDER FANS.AND SOME OF U ALL R NOTHING BUT FAKES.A TRUE STEVIE WONDER CONNOISSEUR IS ONE WHO APPRECIATES HIS COMPLETE CATALOGUE OF SONGS NOT JUST THE HITS,BUT ALSO HIS SELDOM HEARD BUT IGNORED ALTERNATIVE SOUL CLASSICS AND HIS MOST RECENT UNDERAPPRECIATED SONGS. 0393035158|5.0|While everyone is reading The Da Vinci Code and other so-called page-turners, I bought The End of Faith, based solely on a review I had read. Talk about a terrific read. (I've underlined and highlighted so much in it, I probably should have only underlined those very few passages that I DIDN'T feel were worthy of the spotlight.) The footnotes and bibliography bespeak the research and documentation that are so often absent these days from the non-fiction rants that are flooding the bookstores. Here, amazingly, is an author who seems to value scientific thought and process: reason over voodoo. What a refreshing concept, then, given the fact that our so-called role models in DC seem so retro that they'd have us cure diseases with leeches and blood-letting if left to their unchecked philosophical devices! Ron Reagan, of all people, on Larry King a while ago, stated he could never run for president because he's an atheist. (And Harris echoes a similar thought about the type of person who is apt to be elected these days.) How many folks out there are secretly pondering the same themes as Harris and wishing a voice of reason would boldly rise up to say what needs to be said. This author has given voice to those who savor intelligent commentary, as free from spin and dogma as possible, and who believe America is currently on a dangerous track in a dangerous world too complex for the simplistic ideas and narrow world-views of the current Administration. The End of Faith should be on everyone's MUST READ list, hopefully not to get lost, as the diamond it is, in the published manure being churned out by so many hacks. This is one book that I'd give a sixth star to if such a rating were available.
B00003CXQY|3.0|I can't say I was particularly jumping over the moon to see this. I haven't seen a Disney animation since Pocahontas, and don't particularly care to see one ever again, apart from the old classics, like Cinderella, Snow White and Peter Pan. (Just don't sit me down in front of Pinocchio, Sleeping Beauty or any of the Fantasia stuff).<br /><br />The characters are all like previous characters in previous Disney animations. Kuzco was a longer haired version of Aladdin, the male characters apart from Kuzco all had the square jaws reminiscent of the guys in Pocahontas, and Yzma is a mixture of Snow White's evil stepmother and Cruella De Ville. And some of the landscapes look very familiar.<br /><br />I did like the ending, but the rest of the movie didn't really do it for me. And I nearly died when it started, you know a film's gonna be bad, when Tom Jones does the title track! Considering the makers of the film originally wanted to get Sting to sing the opening song but he said he was too old, they need someone more hip and younger. So they went with Tom Jones. Sting is in his 50's, Tom is in his 60's.<br /><br />This is also the first Disney animation to show a pregnant woman, that being Pacha's wife. Never mind falling slightly behind the times, there's also all the hooha about Kuzco and Pacha being slightly more friendly than kids will understand!<br /><br />Like many other Disney films, this one contains a number of hidden Mickey Mouse images. One is in the bushes when Kuzco gets pulled from the water and another is Yzma's head and earrings (upside down).<br /><br />In the scene where Yzma is searching through the various potions she says, \\"Lions, tigers and bears...oh my!\\" a line from The Wizard of Oz. According to producer Randy Fullmer and director Mark Dindal, they were forced to use this joke, which they detested, by then-head of Feature Animation Thomas Schumacher.<br /><br />There's one great line I really did like, you'll probably have to see the film to enjoy it (not that I'm condoning that you understand): \\"Who's in my chair..?\\" \\"Ooh, ooh, I know! I know! Yzma's in your chair!\\"<br /><br />There's loads of extras on this DVD, if you can actually have the time to watch them all. Frankly, they all look frightfully tedious, but if you're into that kinda thing, then goody for you.<br /><br />I really can't recommend this DVD, but I'm still giving it a semi good score. If you wanna see it, go knock yourself out. Kronk by far overshadows Kuzco. And the ending's funny. B0002MPU1K|3.0|If you're looking for some quasi-jazz, pop-music, reminiscent of Michael Buble and Norah Jones, then you've found it in Peter Cincotti's ON THE MOON.  I enjoy listening to it , but not for the same reasons that Cincotti's self-titled debut has become one of my favorite albums.  The sophomore project lacks the quality of Cincotti's first project; the driving bass that embellished many of the songs on the first album seems to have disappeared as have Cincotti's timeless vocals. The very timbre of his voice seems different from track to track on the new album.  The song selection seemed hopeful, paraticularly the first track, which is the best track from ON THE MOON, but it's downhill from there for individuals looking for a good contemporary jazz album.  I'll still listen to ON THE MOON, and enjoy it, but it is a disappointment after Cincotti's smashing debut.

But instead it turned out to be a very expensive popcorn snack and 2 hours of my life I'll never reclaim.

Roughly a 400 page book into what Warner Brothers gave Alfonso (141 minutes) is a very hard thing to do.  One page of script is rougly equal to one minute of screen time.  You obviously cannot fit a 400 page book into a 141 page screenplay.  There are going to be things left out. <br /> <br />The filming is 100x better, the use of colors, scenery, and costume are top notch.  You see Harry, Hermione, and Ron (including all others) in a different light, you see them for once, as teenagers, not as students 24/7.  Even if it's not in the book, these kids DO have a life outside of Hogwarts.  You see Malfoy in an entirely different light, as the coward that he is deep down inside (and you WILL find examples of that in the books...)   <br /> <br />The introduction of Michael Gambon as Professor Dumbledore is harsh at first, but adds a lot to the character.  He loses the \\"caring\\" touch that Richard Harris had, but is very funny.  He is wise, and kooky, and you can see why Harry is so fond of him.  <br /> <br />And people, keep in mind, the decisions are not entirely based on the director.  The production is also affected by the PRODUCER, which is CHRIS COLUMBUS, who directed the first two.  Not to mention, the screenwriter, Steve Kloves, who dearly devotes/devoted years of his life to bringing Harry Potter to life.  He is booked all the way into, at least, 2007 with the movie Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix.  <br /> <br />Overall, I would give this 4.5 stars if possible, but cannot here on Amazon.  It did lack a sort of magic that the first two had, but Harry, Hermione, and Ron are growing up fast.  Hermione blossoms and Ron and Harry are clearly growing into adults.  Malfoy's voice deepens and he even sports a new hair cut.   <br /> <br />Final note:  If you are not a fan of change, you might have a hard time with this one.  It's very different than the first two, but don't go into it, if you haven't seen it, with high expectations.  Let it all happen naturally, and you'll be in for a magical time.

In \\"Gimme three steps\\", \\"Things going on\\" and \\"Mississipi Kid\\", they show us the power of Southern rock. \\"Poison Whiskey\\" is just fantastic; a mix of country and hard rock, really well played. Ronnie Van Zant's voice is the typical southern man voice and it gives the band that good ol' red neck taste. And besides, these guys are able to combine three guitars wonderfully well, making the sound complete. Don't forget to pay attention to keyboards, especially when it comes to that old western piano: just amazing.

6305609705|5.0|One of the best war movies ever made, Apocalypse Now chronicles Lt. Willard's travels upriver through Vietnam and into Cambodia to assasinate a renegade Colonel.<br /><br />Coppola's film is a master of the seemingly incongruous.  In the middle of a bloody attack is a Lt. Colonel who loves surfing.  In the middle of the dark green jungle is an orange and white tiger.  Out of the darkness comes the brightly lit Du Long bridge.  Among the sea of soldiers in an army base are two playboy bunnies in a USO Show.  Amid the destruction and madness at the conclusion of the film is a poetry-quoting colonel and a grungy-looking photojournalist.  The contrasts add much to the film, never out-of-place for the sake of shock value, just adding to the anti-war sentiment that is prevalent throughout the film but rarely overtly declared.<br /><br />Even on the surface this is a very good film.  It follows the basic concept of a road movie (travel from point A to point B, with adventures along the way), the characters are interesting and sufficiently developed, the voiceovers never redundant or too expository, the war scenes very well done, with special notice to the helicopter assault on the village and the chaotic, frenzied but strangely beautiful scene at the Du Long bridge.  9.5/10

I had seen a \\"clown\\" banging a drum back and forth on stage. The guitar riffs are to me much more explosive and heavy as say Black Sabbath's (Vol.4). Now there's an album you won't be able to put down either!<br /><br />By the way, I ordered \\"Iowa\\", and I hope that I am as happy with that as I am with (Verses).

B00005JNEU|4.0|Based on H.G. (\\"Buzz\\") Bissinger's book with the same title and directed by Peter Berg, this film focuses on the Permian (Texas) High School Panthers' 1988 season which ended in the state championship game played in the Houston Astrodome against Dallas Carter High School. Frankly, although I have lived in Texas for almost 30 years and am well aware of the passion which football at all levels generates throughout the state, I still find it difficult to believe the nature and extent of pressure which otherwise sensible adults place on the importance of winning games. Permian coach Gary Gaines (Billy Bob Thornton) is a case in point. If we are to believe Bissinger's account, Gaines was in real danger of losing his job if the Panthers lost the state championship game. (Interestingly, he and his team won it the next year.) The quality of acting throughout the cast is solid but several characters (e.g. Charles Billingsley played by Tim McGraw) seem stereotypical. For whatever reasons, Berg fails to develop any of the leading characters (notably Coach Gaines) beyond what would be revealed in a brief encounter at the local Dairy Queen. In fact, for me at least, the only sympathetic character (if there is one) is the team's star running back, Boobie Miles (Derek Luke), and that's a bit of a stretch, given his peacock personality. The on-field action seems authentic, especially in the championship game. Among sports films, I rate Friday Night Lights comparable with Rudy (1993) and Remember the Titans (2000) but a notch or two below Hoosiers (1986), Varsity Blues (1999), and Miracle (2004). In terms of sustained suspense and dramatic impact, I rate it lower than, for example, The Last Picture Show (1991) with which it shares a few issues in common and Field of Dreams (1989) which, in contrast, celebrates innocence rather than denigrates it as Friday Night Lights does, albeit by implication.
B00000DCER|3.0|Author Stephen Thomas Erlewine once said something like this about \\"The Best Of Friends\\":   \\"This is for people who like to think they like Hooker, but really just want to hear Eric Clapton wail away.\\"    It sounds a bit like the point of view of an old blues purist, perhaps, but one with a lot of truth to it. Many people who aren't attracted to John Lee Hooker's raw, gritty 40s, 50s and 60s recordings will certainly find these guest star-heavy re-recordings much more accessible, and who knows...maybe some of those who got to know John Lee Hooker when he suddenly popped up on MTV at age 73 can use this music as a \\"gateway\\" to the REAL blues.    This is a compilation of songs from the Hook's last five guest star-heavy albums (plus a couple of previously unreleased recordings). There is really nothing here to match Hooker's magnificent VeeJay-recordings, his best ever band backed material, but this is certainly not bad music...with the possible exception of two stylistically challenged numbers, \\"Chill Out\\" and \\"The Healer\\".  Van Morrison appears on two numbers, \\"I Cover The Waterfront\\", and a slow, soulful \\"Don't Look Back\\", playing guitar and singing a verse or two, and his contributions are really the only ones which add something new to the songs.  Eric Clapton plays relatively restrained guitar on a pretty good \\"Boogie Chillen\\", and \\"This Is Hip\\" and \\"Dimples\\" get a nice swaggering groove going, although neither of them come anywhere close to surpassing the original recordings.    \\"Burnin' Hell\\" is marred by the monotonous guitar playing of Ben Harper, and \\"Baby Lee\\" and \\"I'm In The Mood\\" are too slick, but \\"Tupelo\\" is classic John Lee Hooker, just the Hook himself and his guitar and a piece of plywood to stomp on! And \\"Big Legs, Tight Skirt\\" is really good as well, although not as good as Hooker's definitive rendition which he cut for VeeJay in the mid-50s.  Again, this is a pretty good album, especially for \\"casual\\" blues listeners, but it does fall a little flat when compared to the gritty and powerful waxings Hooker made when he was in his prime.
0312263120|3.0|Dan Brown is a master of piquing his reader's curiosity, and then delaying its satisfaction for hundreds of pages. Typical of Da Vinci and Angels and Demons, this book portrays characters deciphering codes to save the world, assassins attempting to kill of the academic heroes, and villains working from the inside. <br /> <br />The depiction of the National Security Agency in this book sounds credible, although it's hard to judge, as the NSA is by nature very secretive. I trust Brown created much of the detail, which I accept as this book is after all, fiction. Brown did a good job suspending my disbelief, and while I had a fairly good idea how the book would end by about the halfway point, I enjoyed reading it. The last few chapters string the suspense out well, although some of the reviewers here felt that part was overdone. <br /> <br />This book is not up to the level of Da Vinci and Angels and Demons, and it does not invovle religion to the extent of his more popular titles. This suspense/thriller is more along the lines of a Clancy novel, so people should not buy it expecting the inside look at Catholicism they may be accustomed to with Brown. The book deals with U.S. intelligence operations and code breaking, excusively. If you ar enot into military/CIa type intrigue, don't get this book.
B000001EL7|4.0|\\"Love Gun\\" is the last great Kiss album where all 4 of the original members play on it. The studio sessions were quite intense because Kiss had been on a virtual non-stop roller coaster for the past 2 years, only now the roller coaster was starting to veer out of control.<br /><br />The Kiss merchandising empire was in full swing by this time and generating a fortune in profits, but the after-effects of this massive success were beginning to take their toll on the band; inner turmoil was developing as well as alcohol and substance abuse problems with Ace Frehley and Peter Criss.<br /><br />But in spite of all this, Kiss still managed to remain focused on their music, and it produced another great album; with the exception of the silly \\"And Then She Kissed Me\\" (don't know whose idea that was!), the album is filled with scorching hard rock classics.<br /><br />\\"I Stole Your Love\\", the great title track, the overlooked \\"Almost Human\\", which features growling vocals from Gene Simmons and another Hendrix-esque feedback guitar solo from Ace Frehley, and the equally overlooked \\"Hooligan\\", which is a nod to Peter Criss' youth growing up in Brooklyn.<br /><br />Last but certainly not least, Ace Frehley makes his lead vocal debut on \\"Shock Me\\"; legend has it that Frehley recorded his vocals while lying on his back so no one could see him singing! Don't know if that's really true, but as flaky as Ace could be sometimes, I wouldn't be surprised if it were!<br /><br />\\"Love Gun\\" belongs in any Kiss fans' CD collection as well as fans of hard rock!

B000001EL3|5.0|Well, I've been on a Kiss kick here lately, so I couldn't pass up the chance to review \\"Destroyer\\"! After the surprise massive success of \\"Alive!\\" the year prior, 1976 marked the arrival of this album and \\"Rock And Roll Over\\" which found Kiss at their creative peak.<br /><br />\\"Destroyer\\" pushed the envelope at the time in terms of experimentation, and proved without a doubt that they could experiment with various things and gain new fans while satisfying their hardcore fan base at the same time; no easy feat by any stretch of the imagination!<br /><br />There isn't a bad song on this album; every one is a remarkable achievement. Beginning with the charging guitars of \\"Detroit Rock City\\" (complete with the devastating car crash sounds at the end) to the sublime orchestration of \\"Beth\\" to the angelic choirs on \\"Great Expectations\\", Kiss leaves almost no stone unturned.<br /><br />Some of the standout tracks are the great \\"Flaming Youth\\", \\"Do You Love Me?\\", \\"King Of The Night Time World\\" (my personal favorite), and Gene Simmons' ode to S&M, \\"Sweet Pain\\". It wasn't until several years ago that I learned Ace Frehley did not play the nasal-sounding guitar solos on \\"Sweet Pain\\"; they were played by Dick Wagner, who was the guitarist for Alice Cooper. I thought at the time that Ace was experimenting with different guitar sounds!<br /><br />As I often like to say, you can't go wrong with this CD! Pick it up if you haven't already!

With love, longing, and a growing understanding, Susie watches her family as they cope with their grief and begin the difficult process of healing.   <br /> This book was an incredible novel. B000001ELF|5.0|By this time, the division bell was already ringing behind the scenes within the Kiss camp, and nothing made the fact more evident that the cookie was crumbling than when Gene, Paul, Ace & Peter released solo albums simultaneously. This also coincided with their movie debut in the made-for-TV disaster \\"Kiss Meets The Phantom Of The Park\\" shown on NBC in October, 1978.<br /><br />Frustrated with the direction that Kiss was headed in at the time as well as with his limited role in the band, Ace Frehley clearly had a statement to make, and he did it with a vengeance on his solo album. Ace's was by far the best of the four albums and definitely rocked the hardest!<br /><br />With the snarling, rabid guitar intro of \\"Rip It Out\\", Ace wastes no time in getting right up in your face to let you know how pi**ed off he is by letting loose with some strong vocals. From this point right through to the end, Ace goes straight for the jugular and doesn't let up a bit.<br /><br />My personal favorite is the echo-laden \\"I'm In Need Of Love\\", where Ace spits out his vocals like venom and in my opinion, unleashes his greatest and most powerful guitar solo since the live version of \\"Shock Me\\" on Alive II.<br /><br />You can clearly hear all the way around just how inspired and motivated Ace was, and this trend continued on even into Kiss' 1979 \\"Dynasty\\" album, the first for the band after regrouping. But shortly thereafter, it was clear to Ace that he would never be completely happy within the confines of Kiss, and thus began the chain of events leading up to his departure in 1982.<br /><br />Every track is a winner here, including several odes to Ace's lifestyle (\\"Ozone\\", \\"Wiped Out\\", \\"Snow Blind\\"), and ends with the great instrumental \\"Fractured Mirror\\", one of the first tracks to contain the use of a guitar synthesizer.<br /><br />This is Ace's finest hour...for some excellent rock & roll, look no further than this!

If one reads more reviews on how the book was bad than one will probably choose not to read this book.  Thus, they will spend some more time trying to find a book that has more of a positive review.  I think that book reviews are far more important than the music and movie reviews. Especially unforgiveable since there's supposed to be a message behind this album.  If you want to hear good metal/punk music with a message, listen to Boy Sets Fire, or even Red Tape. Now Robocop is out to revolutionize the war on crime and protect the citizens of Detroit.<br /><br /> \\"Robocop\\" is without a doubt one of the best action movies of the 1980s and while parts of it do show it's age, it is still quite an impressive movie to watch today, a full 17 years after it was released. I can actually remember although vaguely actually seeing this at the theatre and enjoying it. B00000D9TQ|4.0|When you think about it the 1980's was a terrific decade for popular music.  I would compare it to the sixties.  There were so many creative forces at work and pop music was vibrant and a lot of fun.  When I think of the eighties I think of Phil Collins.  He was not only churning out hit after hit as a solo artist but he was also hitting the charts on a regular basis as the lead singer of Genesis.  And it seemed that every time you turned on the TV there was Phil performing his latest hit.  He was everywhere and to be honest the unlikeliest of rock stars.<br /><br />Atlantic Records released \\"Phil Collins.....Hits\\" back in 1998.  And in spite of the fact that another new 2 disc collection was released in 2004 if you are primarily interested in his biggest hits then this is still by far your best buy. I particularly enjoyed Phil's upbeat pop offerings like \\"Two Hearts\\", \\"Sussidio\\", \\"You Can't Hurry Love\\" and perhaps my favorite tune of the decade \\"Easy Lover\\".  You'll also find #1 tunes like \\"Another Day In Paradise\\", \\"Against All Odds\\" as well as the highly annoying \\"One More Night\\".  How I hated that song!!!!  Am I the only one?  Then there is the unlikely remake of the 1966 hit \\"Groovy Kind of Love\\". Phil managed to take that one all the way to the top of the charts in fall of 1988. Speaking of remakes I also enjoyed Phil's version of the Cindy Lauper hit \\"True Colors\\".  In fact, I think it is far better than the original.  I also wanted to make you aware that a couple of Phil's biggest hits were left off this disc including 1985's \\"Don't Lose My Number\\" and one of his last big chart hits \\"Do You Remember?<br /><br />This is a fine collection of one of the seminal artists of the 1980's.  However, I stopped short of a five star rating due to the complete lack of any meaningful liner notes.  Instead of the usual 8 or 12 page booklet Atlantic instead chose to make this a fold out mini poster. Some may enjoy it but it does nothing for me.  But in spite of this shortcoming I am certain that pop music buffs will enjoy this disc.  Recommended.hat pop music buffs will enjoy this disc.  Recommended.
B0000039LE|5.0|John Carpenter's &#34;Halloween&#34; (1978). Rated &#34;R&#34;. Running Time: One hour, 31 mins<br />Directed by John Carpenter. Written by John Carpenter and Debra Hill.  From Compass International Pictures.<br />First film in the series.<br /><br />Choice of Widescreen or Full Screen.<br /><br />Halloween (1978) is the all-time classic horror film and it still works.  It will scare the goosebumps off of you.  We all remember Janet Leigh (who passed away October 3, 2004) from the Alfred Hitchcock film, [[ASIN:B003IWZ1D8 Psycho (50th Anniversary Edition) [Blu-ray]]] (1960).  Her daughter, Jamie Lee Curtis (also of Tony Curtis)  is the star of Halloween (1978) in this her first film.<br />  John Carpenter was a struggling filmmaker who made this film on a budget of $320,000. For an independent film, it became the most successful released independent film ever made.  They shot the film in 4 weeks for 20 days. The art of suspense, dark shadows, sound, close-up shots, building the story, ultimate surprise and the emotional acting of the actors all make this horror film the greatest scary film ever.<br />  Jamie Lee Curtis plays a high school student, &#34;Laurie Stode&#34;.  There is a stalker, Michael Myers, in the neighborhood.  He killed as a child in 1963, was sent to a mental hospital, escaped as an adult, and is now out to kill again in the same neighborhood.  Michael is a stalker, voyeur, and a cold-blooded killer.  It is Laurie he is truly after.  While Laurie is babysitting two young children on Halloween night, Michael gets his real chance.<br />  This film is the all-time favorite to watch on Halloween night, but due to its effectiveness, it is NOT FOR CHILDREN TO SEE.  There are scenes of sexual situations, female nudity, as well as, intense-violence.<br /><br />  Also in the cast: Donald Pleasence, Nancy Stephens, Nancy Loomis, P.J. Soles, Charles Cyphers, Kyle Richards, Brian Andrews, John Michael Graham, Arthur Malet, Mickey Yablans, Brent Le Page, Adam Hollander, Robert Phalen, Sandy Johnson, David Kyle, and Peter Griffith.<br />  Nick Castle played &#34;Michael Myers&#34;, Tony Moran also plays &#34;Michael Myers&#34; as his face is revealed.  Tommy Lee Wallace played &#34;Michael Myers&#34; in the bedroom closet scenes. Will Sandin plays &#34;Michael&#34; as a child.<br /><br />Filmed in South Pasadena, Sierra Madre, Alhambra, City of Industry, Rosemead, North Hollywood, Hollywood, Burbank, California.<br /><br />In-film advertising: Jolly Time Pop Corn, Tide, Clorox 2, Quaker Oats, Budweiser.<br /><br />English language only. B00003CXA3|5.0|Let's just get the plot synopsis out of the way: Popeye Doyle and Cloudy Russo are to NYPD detectives who make the largest heroin bust of their time.  As the title implies, heroin is being smuggled in by a prominent Frenchman and sold through middlemen in Manhattan.  Doyle and Russo do an amazing job of tracking down the bad guys, but unfortunately, the bad guys still claim somewhat of a victory in the end. The movie's based on a true story, but of course, many liberties are taken. Alright, that's that. <br /> <br />This is simply one of the greatest movies I have ever seen. Gene Hackman never topped himself with his Oscar-winning performance as Popeye Doyle.  He's able to channel the obsessiveness, harshness, and faux racism of the actual person he's based on so genuinely that you wouldn't doubt that he's an actual hardened detective. Roy Scheider does an outstanding job as Popeye's sidekick Cloudy. He plays Cloudy a bit more mellow than Popeye, but you can tell that he's just as good a cop as his partner. The cast also includes Fernando Rey who turns in a great performance as the French villain. <br /> <br />Of course, the acting is superb, but the cinematography and the action are equally great.  Since Friedkin wanted the movie shot in a documentary style, the on-screen action takes on a very realistic appearance.  This enhances our appreciation of the New York that is seldom portrayed - the non-5th-avenue, real, heroin-infested backstreets of the 60's.  And, yes of course, one of the greatest chases in the history of movies - Popeye in a car chasing the French hitman who's on a train.  There's no CGI here.  And as you'll learn from the commentaries, the crashes you see are real since the filmmakers didn't bother to obtain permits to shoot on the streets and instead just stole the shots. <br /> <br />That brings me to the DVD extras. The commentary by director Friedkin is excellent.  It really gave me a new appreciation for this movie.   Friedkin talks at lengthabout the 2 detectives the main characters are based on, the difficulties in making the movie, and probably most interesting to a film fanatic, the correlations between the movie and the actual case itself.  The commentaries by Hackman and Scheider are also great, but unfortunately, each only speak for about 20-30 minutes. The DVD also has an insightful documentary produced by the BBC about the movie and the actual case. <br /> <br />I'm sorry I'm talking so long, but there's still more to say. There are seven 7 deleted scenes and accompanying commentaries on the DVD. After viewing these, I realized just how revolutionary the ideas behind this movie actually were. The final cut of the movie was controversial enough in its portrayals of drug use, police behavior, and Popeye's racist attitudes, but one look at the deleted scenes will convince you that Friedkin would have pushed the envelope farther if only audiences were ready for it. The most striking of the scenes depicts the French hitman enjoying sadomasochistic activities with a prostitute. That may be par for the course for today's movies, but just imagine what it would have been like back then. <br /> <br />I've rambled enough, but it's only because I love this movie and this DVD. Make sure you pick it up next time you go to Blockbuster or wherever.

B00005OM4N|3.0|Britney Spears' 3rd album is good, but uneven in some places.  The first half is funky and edgy with songs like I'm A Slave For You, Boys, Overprotected and others.  But the second half sounds too '80s like.  Cinderella sounds too Bon Jovi like, Bombastic Love would have sounded good in 1986, and the Wade Robson and Justin Timberlake produced offerings are lame and sound like rejects from her '99 debut. Her I'm Not A Girl, Not Yet a Woman is a pretty, gorgeous ballad--sounds like she's lived it in the lyrics, despite the Dido-songwriting assist. Her offerings with Rodney Jerkins and Neptunes give the Max Martin and Kierulf/Schwartz songs some stiff competition.  But it is not her best album; she seems lost in some of the production and music of the songs. Sometimes the music is louder than Spears' voice, what with the heavy beats and basslines. And as for her calling this her most mature album, it isn't--that belongs to her 4th, In The Zone. This album just saw Britney struggling to stay afloat against the competition--it's really missing something, lacks the pizazz of Britney's first two albums.
B00004TH7Z|4.0|I give this album four stars because it is an excellent metal and Maiden album, but not one I would say merits the utmost honor and rating.  First of all as a Maiden album BNW is different than others. If you like Maiden's early, middle and later periods (Iron Maiden and Killers, Number of the Beast through Seventh Son and Fear of the Dark to the present) or a combination of those then I would suggest this album.  If you only like a few Maiden songs, this would not be your best bet.  Go look for Rock in Rio.  Secondly, if it is not obvious Maiden has evolved, whether in your opinion for better of for worse.  This means this album cannot easily be compared with other Maiden albums, but maybe songs.  I will use Maiden songs as a breakdown for comparison (except songs from Dance of Death, too easy).  <br /> <br />The Wickerman- Great album opener, bass is obvious, catchy, simple chorus.  Anthem like.  Compare it to The Evil That Men Do. <br /> <br />Ghost of The Navigator- Another great song, builds and culminates in a nice breakdown into the chorus, catchy riffs, biting. Compare it to The Fugitive. <br /> <br />Brave New World- Slow, melodic start, builds rather slowly, sad almost poignantly, heavier than most on this album.  Compare it to Fear of the Dark. <br /> <br />Blood Brothers- Orchestral accompaniment, slower, melodic as well, simple chorus, nice ending solos and vocal harmonies.  Compare it to Infinite Dreams. <br /> <br />The Mercenary- Great track, fast-paced, basic verse/chorus/solo/bridge pattern, shredding solos, great sing-a-long.  Compare it to The Trooper. <br /> <br />Dream of Mirrors- slower, longer, heavy breakdown with killer solos and vocals, takes longer to fully enjoy.  Compare it to The Clansman. <br /> <br />The Fallen Angel- Very heavy, crunching, like Mercenary in style, but opposite in speed and rhythm, good middle track.  Compare it to Caught Somewhere in Time. <br /> <br />The Nomad- long, repetitive, deep/low/slower, melodic solo section with orchestration in middle (rather cool).  Compare it to To Tame A Land. <br /> <br />Out of The Silent Planet- more up-beat, builds nicely, great chorus and opening break to verse, awesome guitar work (harmonies, solos, and obvious three parts).  Compare it to  <br />Two Minutes To Midnight. <br /> <br />The Thin Line Between Love and Hate- Crushing, slower, optimistic, nice vocal range show off for Bruce, very melodic and slow almost acoustical seeming at end.  Compare it to Still Life. <br /> <br />Overall great album if you like Maiden a lot, if you don't wait a little.  If you have Maiden albums from early and later periods this is most likely the best from their last four studio albums.  If your a new fan get one of the first two albums, Number of the beast, Powerslave, and Seventh Son of a Seventh Son before Brave New World.

B00005JMJG|5.0|ETERNAL SUNSHINE OF THE SPOTLESS MIND is as original and fascinating as anything Charlie Kaufman has written previously. Kaufman has the ability to take a tiny thought/idea and trace it through the minds of his characters much like the way synapses propel sensory input.  And in doing so he provides more intelligent insights about personality variations and relationships and the vulnerability and neediness of contemporary man than just about any person writing scripts today.  This is 21st Century existentialism delivered in the most cogent manner.<br /><br />But the story would be only half told were it not for director Michel Gondry and his enormously gifted cast of characters:  Jim Carrey finally demonstrates his innate thespian gifts with the role of Joel, a laid back, fearful, needy cookie-cutter piece of a man who finally finds someone who loves him in goofy Clementine (the always superb Kate Winslet) only to have the 'business' of memory erasing (run by Dr. Miarzwiak - Tom Wilkinson - assisted by his technicians Mark Ruffalo and Elijah Wood) destroy his new found happiness and drive him to the same extreme that drove Clementine to have their memories of each other erased.  Despite the apparent linear storyline this film begins to act like the confusion of electrical stimuli to brain cells and for the remainder of the the movie we are not sure how the idea is playing out until the magic ending which is so fine that it should be withheld from those who have not experienced this film.  This is cinema of the first rank, up there in the echelon of Resnais, Fellini, Almodovar and others who have been practitioneers of the bizarre yet wholly committed art of mind manipulation.  This film may take some work from you, may require a couple of watchings, but it is time well spent.  Let's hope there are more collaborations between Kaufman and Gondry - and even this cast - in the future!
B00003CXCT|5.0|Well, I bought the STAR WARS Trilogy DVD and I just got through watching all the movies, special features, commentaries, etc. And it was lots and lots of fun.  <br /> <br />The image and sound quality are top notch, of course. These movies no doubt look and sound better here than they ever have before.  <br /> <br />As for the changes made by George Lucas: they're jarring, but most of them I think I will get used to. A few tweaks here and there aren't really all that bad -- I like the shots of the different planets celebrating at the end of RETURN, along with the new music that replaces that awful Ewok chant, and it's nice to finally get to meet Biggs right before the big attack on the Death Star. I'm even beginning to accept the addition of Hayden Christensen as Annikin alongside Obi-Wan and Yoda at the end of RETURN. And I don't mind the original bug-eyed Emperor in EMPIRE being replaced by Ian McDiarmid, because he didn't match the character in RETURN anyway. (One thing I still can't figure out -- why does there seem to be a crudely-drawn black spot next to the Emperor's right eye during his final scenes in RETURN? It looks as though it's masking something, but what?) <br /> <br />Some of the additions were unnecessary -- I really didn't need to actually see a hand-puppetty-looking worm coming out of that hole that Boba Fett falls into on Tattooine during the scene on Jabba's barge. Nor does seeing a herd of Banthas, or stormtroopers riding around on digital beasts, add anything to my enjoyment of the movies. Most of it is just George Lucas' irritating tendency to forever tinker around with his creations. However -- <br /> <br />Some of the changes that particularly irritated me are: <br /> <br />1. Greedo still shoots first, although they made the time between his shot and Han's shot shorter -- but who cares? I liked Han better when he just pre-emptively shot first. That totally fits his character at the time. <br />2. The scene where Jabba confronts Han beforethe Millenium Falcon takes off is all wrong. Jabba always struck me as a creature who is naturally too huge and bloated to be very mobile -- as in RETURN, where he lounges authoritatively in one spot and everything and everyone comes to HIM -- and it just looks dumb to see him bopping around like this.  <br />3. The rebel fighters heading toward the Death Star are digital now. I liked the old ones. George -- I LIKE seeing how the FX guys conquered challenges using the resources available at the time and managed to produce great effects that STILL LOOK GOOD. <br />4. Boba Fett's voice is now the voice of the actor who plays Jango Fett in CLONES. So how come the stormtroopers don't all sound like him too? <br />5. The dancers performing for Jabba the Hut do a digital song-and-dance sequence now. It's pretty bad -- like something out of a third-rate Pixar movie. <br /> <br />I'm sure I'll think of some others later, but you get the idea. The changes are there, and we're stuck with them, so we might as well get used to them. Although this is why I wish the DVD's came with both the original versions and the \\"special\\" editions.  <br /> <br />The commentaries are pretty interesting for the most part. Lucas, Dennis Muren, sound designer Ben Burtt, and Carrie Fisher appear on all three, with the addition of director Irvin Kershner on EMPIRE. There aren't many dead spots, but that's mainly because Burtt goes on and on about how he obtained various sounds from dumpster lids, movie projectors, and whatnot. It's interesting in small doses, but he goes on about it too much during scenes where I would like to hear commentary from Lucas or Muren. Kershner is a genial old guy who seems genuinely enthusiastic about his part in the STAR WARS saga and it's fun to listen to him, even though a lot of his commentary is simply him excitedly telling us what's going on as it happens. Fisher pops in now and then with a few anecdotes.  <br /> <br />Lucas' commentary contributions, of course, are the most substantive, yet he frequently made me want to throw things at him with his constant griping about how unsatisfied he was with various shots and how this or that could've been done better digitally. Before it was over I was thoroughly sick and tired of the word \\"digital.\\" I feel that, like myself, a lot of the people watching these movies, who have loved them for decades, are entirely content with the way they look and how the FX artists of the time were able to solve certain problems and present incredible special effects that, as I said before, STILL LOOK GOOD even after the advent of CGI and other advanced techniques. I wanted to hear how these movies were made, not how much better they could have been made today. Lucas, however, seems totally oblivious to this and often speaks in a regretful tone during the commentary, which is a real turn-off. He just doesn't seem to get the fact that these movies are so popular because of what they are, not because of what they could have been. <br /> <br />As for the additional disc of special features, there's a wonderful documentary about the STAR WARS saga that lasts around two-and-a-half hours. There are also three featurettes of interest, especially the one which features the likes of Ridley Scott, James Cameron, and Peter Jackson talking about the effect STAR WARS has had on them. In addition to the usual trailers, TV spots, etc., there's a preview of Episode III that shows Hayden Christensen and Ewen MacGregor practising what promises to be a major lightsaber dual between their characters, and the construction of a new Darth Vader costume. The video game preview is interesting too, and contains more of Christensen going through his moves for the benefit of the game designers.  <br /> <br />An Easter egg which can be found on the \\"Video Games And Still Galleries\\" menu features some outtakes along with the DVD credits. It's not very long and it seems as though more of this material could have been dug up forthe DVD. (You can access it by punching in \\"11\\", which activates a light next to R2-D2, then \\"3\\", and then \\"8\\".) The still galleries contain photos from the discarded sequence in which Luke hangs out with his friend Biggs Darklighter at Tosche Station in Anchorhead (surprisingly, Koo Stark was in this scene as well) which makes one wonder why Lucas couldn't have included these scenes on the special features disc as well. One possible reason is the fact that a special, SPECIAL set of all six films is already being planned and they're saving stuff like that for it. Which means, I guess, that I'm going to miss out on it because there's no way I'm buying these movies AGAIN. <br /> <br />Well, that's my disjointed review of the new STAR WARS DVD set. All in all, despite its flaws, it's definitely well worth having and is a huge amount of fun for the Star Wars fan. <br /> <br />
B0002VKZL6|4.0|I consider Knopfler the only guitarist that can still make the overused Stratocaster tone sound interesting.  That said, I've only sporatically liked his own work, and I usually prefer his music when he's backing someone else like Steely Dan or Dylan.  Shangri La proves to be an exception.  The songwriting is very solid and strikes a great balance between blues rock and Knopfler's recent British folk interests.
